availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

person.persName: Selby Harney (Louisville, Kentucky, attorney, editor, and soldier.)

body.p: Louisville, Kentucky, attorney, editor, and soldier. Kentucky native. Son of John H. Harney and Martha Wallace Harney. Married to Caroline R. Taylor Harney in Hamilton County, Ohio, on September 17, 1859. Father of Selby Harney, Jr., John H. Harney, and Elizabeth Harney. Attended school in Louisville, Kentucky, in 1850. Household owned one enslaved person in Louisville in 1850. Attorney in partnership with William W. Harney in the law firm Harney & Bro., in Louisville in 1860. Editor of the Louisville Daily Democrat in Louisville in 1860. Served in the Louisville Provost Guard (U.S.A.) as a major from March 10, 1862, to October 3, 1862. Served in the 34th Kentucky Volunteer Infantry Regiment (U.S.A.) as a major, lieutenant colonel, and colonel, from October 3, 1862, to December 15, 1863. Attorney in partnership with William G. Reasor in the law firm Reasor & Harney in Louisville in 1865.

ab.bibl:
